messageBody:
Hello all

I'm new to the unit testing world and I've been learning from this two last weeks how to use the JUnit framework; so far I have no problems with the simple projects I've made, but now I'm a bit stumped. I develop over a set of frameworks which give me the skeleton for many of the classes I make. From it I can add my own code. In such cases, the classes inherit from a parent class where some kind of initialization is made. Well, is my understand that the test classes that I can make using JUnit have to set up the fixture using instance variables, but in my case I already have the set up made due to the parent initialization and I would like to take advantage of it. So, I tried to do the reverse: I made an inner class which extends TestCase within the class I want to test. But then I can't use the automatic way to create suites because JUnit doesn't extract the testMethods from the inner class.
This is a little example of one of my tries:

public class MyClass extends ParentClass {
private String name;
public MyClass( String name ) {
this.name = name;
}
public String name() {
return "I am a " + name;
}

public static void main( String[] ar ) {
MyClass aThing = new MyClass( "thing" );
// Problem: This parameter isn't accepted by the
// compiler.
junit.textui.TestRunner( MyClass$TestMyClass.class );
}

public static class TestMyClass extends TestCase {
// The setup

public void testName() {
//test code here
}

public static Test suite() {
// Problem: How can I tell JUnit that
// the test methods are inside the inner class?
return new TestSuite( MyClass$TestMyClass.class );
}
}
}

So, the questions are:
Can this kind of setup be done with JUnit or am I going to do my own test classes? Have I misunderstood how JUnit works?
I guess that my Java knowledge still is far from expert level...

TIA, Santi.
